column1: manum ekāgram āsīnam abhigamya maharṣayaḥ / pratipūjya yathānyāyam idaṃ vacanam abruvan //
column2: The great sages approached Manu, who was seated with a collected mind, and, having duly worshipped him, spoke as follows:

column1: bhagavan sarvavarṇānāṃ yathāvad anupūrvaśaḥ / antaraprabhavānāṃ ca dharmān no vaktum arhasi //
column2: 'Deign, divine one, to declare to us precisely and in due order the sacred laws of each of the (four chief) castes (varna) and of the intermediate ones.

column2: 'For thou, O Lord, alone knowest the purport, (i.e.) the rites, and the knowledge of the soul, (taught) in this whole ordinance of the Self-existent (Svayambhu), which is unknowable and unfathomable.'

column2: He, whose power is measureless, being thus asked by the high-minded great sages, duly honoured them, and answered, 'Listen!'

column2: Then the divine Self-existent (Svayambhu, himself) indiscernible, (but) making (all) this, the great elements and the rest, discernible, appeared with irresistible (creative) power, dispelling the darkness.

column1: yo 'sāv atīndriyagrāhyaḥ sūkṣmo 'vyaktaḥ sanātanaḥ / sarvabhūtamayo 'cintyaḥ sa eva svayam udbabhau //
column2: He who can be perceived by the internal organ (alone), who is subtile, indiscernible, and eternal, who contains all created beings and is inconceivable, shone forth of his own (will).

column1: so 'bhidhyāya śarīrāt svāt sisṛkṣur vividhāḥ prajāḥ / apa eva sasarjādau tāsu vīryam avāsṛjat //
column2: He, desiring to produce beings of many kinds from his own body, first with a thought created the waters, and placed his seed in them.

column1: tad aṇḍam abhavad dhaimaṃ sahasrāṃśusamaprabham / tasmiñ jajñe svayaṃ brahmā sarvalokapitāmahaḥ //
column2: That (seed) became a golden egg, in brilliancy equal to the sun; in that (egg) he himself was born as Brahman, the progenitor of the whole world.

column2: The waters are called narah, (for) the waters are, indeed, the offspring of Nara; as they were his first residence (ayana), he thence is named Narayana.

column1: yat tat kāraṇam avyaktaṃ nityaṃ sadasadātmakaṃ / tadvisṛṣṭaḥ sa puruṣo loke brahmeti kīrtyate //
column2: From that (first) cause, which is indiscernible, eternal, and both real and unreal, was produced that male (Purusha), who is famed in this world (under the appellation of) Brahman.

column1: tasminn aṇḍe sa bhagavān uṣitvā parivatsaram / svayam evātmano dhyānāt tad aṇḍam akarod dvidhā //
column2: The divine one resided in that egg during a whole year, then he himself by his thought (alone) divided it into two halves;

column1: tābhyāṃ sa śakalābhyāṃ ca divaṃ bhūmiṃ ca nirmame / madhye vyoma diśaś cāṣṭāv apāṃ sthānaṃ ca śāśvataṃ //
column2: And out of those two halves he formed heaven and earth, between them the middle sphere, the eight points of the horizon, and the eternal abode of the waters.

column1: udbabarhātmanaś caiva manaḥ sadasadātmakam / manasaś cāpy ahaṃkāram abhimantāram īśvaram //
column2: From himself (atmanah) he also drew forth the mind, which is both real and unreal, likewise from the mind egoism, which possesses the function of self-consciousness (and is) lordly;

column1: mahāntam eva cātmānaṃ sarvāṇi triguṇāni ca / viṣayāṇāṃ grahītṝṇi śanaiḥ pañcendriyāṇi ca //
column2: Moreover, the great one, the soul, and all (products) affected by the three qualities, and, in their order, the five organs which perceive the objects of sensation.

column1: teṣāṃ tv avayavān sūkṣmān ṣaṇṇām apy amitaujasām / saṃniveśyātmamātrāsu sarvabhūtāni nirmame //
column2: But, joining minute particles even of those six, which possess measureless power, with particles of himself, he created all beings.

column1: yan mūrtyavayavāḥ sūkṣmās tānīmāny āśrayanti ṣaṭ / tasmāc charīram ity āhus tasya mūrtiṃ manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: Because those six (kinds of) minute particles, which form the (creator's) frame, enter (a-sri) these (creatures), therefore the wise call his frame sarira, (the body.)

column1: tad āviśanti bhūtāni mahānti saha karmabhiḥ / manaś cāvayavaiḥ sūkṣmaiḥ sarvabhūtakṛd avyayam //
column2: That the great elements enter, together with their functions and the mind, through its minute parts the framer of all beings, the imperishable one.

column1: teṣām idaṃ tu saptānāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ mahaujasām / sūkṣmābhyo mūrtimātrābhyaḥ saṃbhavaty avyayād vyayam //
column2: But from minute body (-framing) particles of these seven very powerful Purushas springs this (world), the perishable from the imperishable.

column1: ādyādyasya guṇaṃ tv eṣām avāpnoti paraḥ paraḥ / yo yo yāvatithaś caiṣāṃ sa sa tāvad guṇaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: Among them each succeeding (element) acquires the quality of the preceding one, and whatever place (in the sequence) each of them occupies, even so many qualities it is declared to possess.

column1: sarveṣāṃ tu sa nāmāni karmāṇi ca pṛthak pṛthak / vedaśabdebhya evādau pṛthak saṃsthāś ca nirmame //
column2: But in the beginning he assigned their several names, actions, and conditions to all (created beings), even according to the words of the Veda.

column1: karmātmanāṃ ca devānāṃ so 'sṛjat prāṇināṃ prabhuḥ / sādhyānāṃ ca gaṇaṃ sūkṣmaṃ yajñaṃ caiva sanātanam //
column2: He, the Lord, also created the class of the gods, who are endowed with life, and whose nature is action; and the subtile class of the Sadhyas, and the eternal sacrifice.

column1: agnivāyuravibhyas tu trayaṃ brahma sanātanam / dudoha yajñasiddhyartham ṛgyajuḥsāmalakṣaṇam //
column2: But from fire, wind, and the sun he drew forth the threefold eternal Veda, called Rik, Yagus, and Saman, for the due performance of the sacrifice.

column1: kālaṃ kālavibhaktīś ca nakṣatrāṇi grahāṃs tathā / saritaḥ sāgarāñ śailān samāni viṣamāni ca //
column2: Time and the divisions of time, the lunar mansions and the planets, the rivers, the oceans, the mountains, plains, and uneven ground.

column1: tapo vācaṃ ratiṃ caiva kāmaṃ ca krodham eva ca / sṛṣṭiṃ sasarja caivemāṃ sraṣṭum icchann imāḥ prajāḥ //
column2: Austerity, speech, pleasure, desire, and anger, this whole creation he likewise produced, as he desired to call these beings into existence.

column1: karmaṇāṃ ca vivekārthaṃ dharmādharmau vyavecayat / dvandvair ayojayac cemāḥ sukhaduḥkhādibhiḥ prajāḥ //
column2: Moreover, in order to distinguish actions, he separated merit from demerit, and he caused the creatures to be affected by the pairs (of opposites), such as pain and pleasure.

column1: aṇvyo mātrā vināśinyo daśārdhānāṃ tu yāḥ smṛtāḥ / tābhiḥ sārdham idaṃ sarvaṃ saṃbhavaty anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: But with the minute perishable particles of the five (elements) which have been mentioned, this whole (world) is framed in due order.

column1: yaṃ tu karmaṇi yasmin sa nyayuṅkta prathamaṃ prabhuḥ / sa tad eva svayaṃ bheje sṛjyamānaḥ punaḥ punaḥ //
column2: But to whatever course of action the Lord at first appointed each (kind of beings), that alone it has spontaneously adopted in each succeeding creation.

column1: hiṃsrāhiṃsre mṛdukrūre dharmādharmāv ṛtānṛte / yad yasya so 'dadhāt sarge tat tasya svayam āviśat //
column2: Whatever he assigned to each at the (first) creation, noxiousness or harmlessness, gentleness or ferocity, virtue or sin, truth or falsehood, that clung (afterwards) spontaneously to it.

column1: yathā rtuliṅgāny ṛtavaḥ svayam eva rtuparyaye / svāni svāny abhipadyante tathā karmāṇi dehinaḥ //
column2: As at the change of the seasons each season of its own accord assumes its distinctive marks, even so corporeal beings (resume in new births) their (appointed) course of action.

column1: lokānāṃ tu vivṛddhyarthaṃ mukhabāhūrupādataḥ / brāhmaṇaṃ kṣatriyaṃ vaiśyaṃ śūdraṃ ca niravartayat //
column2: But for the sake of the prosperity of the worlds he caused the Brahmana, the Kshatriya, the Vaisya, and the Sudra to proceed from his mouth, his arms, his thighs, and his feet.

column1: dvidhā kṛtvātmano deham ardhena puruṣo 'bhavat / ardhena nārī tasyāṃ sa virājam asṛjat prabhuḥ // tapas taptvāsṛjad yaṃ tu sa svayaṃ puruṣo virāṭ / taṃ māṃ vittāsya sarvasya sraṣṭāraṃ dvijasattamāḥ //
column2: Dividing his own body, the Lord became half male and half female; with that (female) he produced Virag. But know me, O most holy among the twice-born, to be the creator of this whole (world), whom that male, Virag, himself produced, having performed austerities.

column1: ahaṃ prajāḥ sisṛkṣus tu tapas taptvā suduścaram / patīn prajānām asṛjaṃ maharṣīn ādito daśa //
column2: Then I, desiring to produce created beings, performed very difficult austerities, and (thereby) called into existence ten great sages, lords of created beings,

column1: marīcim atryaṅgirasau pulastyaṃ pulahaṃ kratum / pracetasaṃ vasiṣṭhaṃ ca bhṛguṃ nāradam eva ca //
column2: Mariki, Atri, Angiras, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kratu, Praketas, Vasishtha, Bhrigu, and Narada.

column1: ete manūṃs tu saptān yān asṛjan bhūritejasaḥ / devān devanikāyāṃś ca maharṣīṃś cāmitaujasaḥ //
column2: They created seven other Manus possessing great brilliancy, gods and classes of gods and great sages of measureless power,

column1: yakṣarakṣaḥpiśācāṃś ca gandharvāpsaraso 'surān / nāgān sarpān suparṇāṃś ca pitṝṇāṃś ca pṛthaggaṇam //
column2: Yakshas (the servants of Kubera, the demons called) Rakshasas and Pisakas, Gandharvas (or musicians of the gods), Apsarases (the dancers of the gods), Asuras, (the snake-deities called) Nagas and Sarpas, (the bird-deities called) Suparnas and the several classes of the manes,

column1: kinnarān vānarān matsyān vividhāṃś ca vihaṅgamān / paśūn mṛgān manuṣyāṃś ca vyālāṃś cobhayatodataḥ // kṛmikīṭapataṅgāṃś ca yūkāmakṣikamatkuṇam / sarvaṃ ca daṃśamaśakaṃ sthāvaraṃ ca pṛthagvidham //
column2: Lightnings, thunderbolts and clouds, imperfect (rohita) and perfect rainbows, falling meteors, supernatural noises, comets, and heavenly lights of many kinds,39 (Horse-faced) Kinnaras, monkeys, fishes, birds of many kinds, cattle, deer, men, and carnivorous beasts with two rows of teeth, Small and large worms and beetles, moths, lice, flies, bugs, all stinging and biting insects and the several kinds of immovable things.

column1: evam etair idaṃ sarvaṃ manniyogān mahātmabhiḥ / yathākarma tapoyogāt sṛṣṭaṃ sthāvarajaṅgamam //
column2: Thus was this whole (creation), both the immovable and the movable, produced by those high-minded ones by means of austerities and at my command, (each being) according to (the results of) its actions.

column1: yeṣāṃ tu yādṛṣaṃ karma bhūtānām iha kīrtitam / tat tathā vo 'bhidhāsyāmi kramayogaṃ ca janmani //
column2: But whatever act is stated (to belong) to (each of) those creatures here below, that I will truly declare to you, as well as their order in respect to birth.

column1: paśavaś ca mṛgāś caiva vyālāś cobhayatodataḥ / rakṣāṃsi ca piśācāś ca manuṣyāś ca jarāyujāḥ // aṇḍājāḥ pakṣiṇaḥ sarpā nakrā matsyāś ca kacchapāḥ / yāni caivaM: prakārāṇi sthalajāny audakāni ca //

From hot moisture spring stinging and biting insects, lice, flies, bugs, and all other (creatures) of that kind which are produced by heat.

column1: udbhijjāḥ sthāvarāḥ sarve bījakāṇḍaprarohiṇaḥ / oṣadhyaḥ phalapākāntā bahupuṣpaphalopagāḥ // apuṣpāḥ phalavanto ye te vanaspatayaḥ smṛtāḥ / puṣpiṇaḥ phalinaś caiva vṛkṣās tūbhayataḥ smṛtāḥ // gucchagulmaṃ tu vividhaṃ tathaiva tṛṇajātayaḥ / bījakāṇḍaruhāṇy eva pratānā vallya eva ca //
column2: All plants, propagated by seed or by slips, grow from shoots; annual plants (are those) which, bearing many flowers and fruits, perish after the ripening of their fruit; (Those trees) which bear fruit without flowers are called vanaspati (lords of the forest); but those which bear both flowers and fruit are called vriksha. But the various plants with many stalks, growing from one or several roots, the different kinds of grasses, the climbing plants and the creepers spring all from seed or from slips.

column1: tamasā bahurūpeṇa veṣṭitāḥ karmahetunā / antaḥsaṃjñā bhavanty ete sukhaduḥkhasamanvitāḥ //
column2: These (plants) which are surrounded by multiform Darkness, the result of their acts (in former existences), possess internal consciousness and experience pleasure and pain.

column1: etadantās tu gatayo brahmādyāḥ samudāhṛtāḥ / ghore 'smin bhūtasaṃsāre nityaṃ satatayāyini //
column2: The (various) conditions in this always terrible and constantly changing circle of births and deaths to which created beings are subject, are stated to begin with (that of) Brahman, and to end with (that of) these (just mentioned immovable creatures).

column1: evaṃ sarvaṃ sa sṛṣṭvedaṃ māṃ cācintyaparākramaḥ / ātmany antardadhe bhūyaḥ kālaṃ kālena pīḍayan //
column2: When he whose power is incomprehensible, had thus produced the universe and men, he disappeared in himself, repeatedly suppressing one period by means of the other.

column1: yadā sa devo jāgarti tad evaṃ ceṣṭate jagat / yadā svapiti śāntātmā tadā sarvaṃ nimīlati //
column2: When that divine one wakes, then this world stirs; when he slumbers tranquilly, then the universe sinks to sleep.

column1: tasmin svapiti tu svasthe karmātmānaḥ śarīriṇaḥ / svakarmabhyo nivartante manaś ca glānim ṛcchati //
column2: But when he reposes in calm sleep, the corporeal beings whose nature is action, desist from their actions and mind becomes inert.

column1: yugapat tu pralīyante yadā tasmin mahātmani / tadāyaṃ sarvabhūtātmā sukhaṃ svapiti nirvṛtaḥ //
column2: When they are absorbed all at once in that great soul, then he who is the soul of all beings sweetly slumbers, free from all care and occupation.

column1: tamo 'yaṃ tu samāśritya ciraṃ tiṣṭhati sendriyaḥ / na ca svaṃ kurute karma tadotkrāmati mūrtitaḥ //
column2: When this (soul) has entered darkness, it remains for a long time united with the organs (of sensation), but performs not its functions; it then leaves the corporeal frame.

column1: yadāṇumātriko bhūtvā bījaṃ sthāsnu cariṣṇu ca / samāviśati saṃsṛṣṭas tadā mūrtiṃ vimuñcati //
column2: When, being clothed with minute particles (only), it enters into vegetable or animal seed, it then assumes, united (with the fine body), a (new) corporeal frame.

column1: evaṃ sa jāgratsvapnābhyām idaṃ sarvaṃ carācaram / saṃjīvayati cājasraṃ pramāpayati cāvyayaḥ //
column2: Thus he, the imperishable one, by (alternately) waking and slumbering, incessantly revivifies and destroys this whole movable and immovable (creation).

column2: But he having composed these Institutes (of the sacred law), himself taught them, according to the rule, to me alone in the beginning; next I (taught them) to Mariki and the other sages.

column1: etad vo 'yaṃ bhṛguḥ śāstraṃ śrāvayiṣyaty aśesataḥ / etad dhi matto 'dhijage sarvam eṣo 'khilaṃ muniḥ //
column2: Bhrigu, here, will fully recite to you these Institutes; for that sage learned the whole in its entirety from me.

column1: tatas tathā sa tenokto maharṣimanunā bhṛguḥ / tān abravīd ṛṣīn sarvān prītātmā śrūyatām iti //
column2: Then that great sage Bhrigu, being thus addressed by Manu, spoke, pleased in his heart, to all the sages, 'Listen!'

column1: svāyaṃbhuvasyāsya manoḥ ṣaḍvaṃśyā manavo 'pare / sṛṣṭavantaḥ prajāḥ svāḥ svā mahātmāno mahaujasaḥ //
column2: Six other high-minded, very powerful Manus, who belong to the race of this Manu, the descendant of the Self-existent (Svayambhu), and who have severally produced created beings,

column1: svārociṣaś cottamaś ca tāmaso raivatas tathā / cākṣuṣaś ca mahātejā vivasvatsuta eva ca //
column2: (Are) Svarokisha, Auttami, Tamasa, Raivata, Kakshusha, possessing great lustre, and the son of Vivasvat.

column1: nimeṣā daśa cāṣṭau ca kāṣṭhā triṃśat tu tāḥ kalā / triṃśat kalā muhūrtaḥ syād ahorātraṃ tu tāvataḥ //
column2: Eighteen nimeshas (twinklings of the eye, are one kashtha), thirty kashthas one kala, thirty kalas one muhurta, and as many (muhurtas) one day and night.

column1: ahorātre vibhajate sūryo mānuṣadaivike / rātriḥ svapnāya bhūtānāṃ ceṣṭāyai karmaṇām ahaḥ //

column1: pitrye rātryahanī māsaḥ pravibhāgas tu pakṣayoḥ / karmaceṣṭāsv ahaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ śuklaḥ svapnāya śarvarī //
column2: A month is a day and a night of the manes, but the division is according to fortnights. The dark (fortnight) is their day for active exertion, the bright (fortnight) their night for sleep.

column1: daive rātryahanī varṣaṃ pravibhāgas tayoḥ punaḥ / ahas tatrodagayanaṃ rātriḥ syād dakṣiṇāyanam //
column2: A year is a day and a night of the gods; their division is (as follows): the half year during which the sun progresses to the north will be the day, that during which it goes southwards the night.

column1: brāhmasya tu kṣapāhasya yat pramāṇaṃ samāsataḥ / ekaikaśo yugānāṃ tu kramaśas tan nibodhata //
column2: But hear now the brief (description of) the duration of a night and a day of Brahman and of the several ages (of the world, yuga) according to their order.

column1: catvāry āhuḥ sahasrāṇi varsāṇāṃ tat kṛtaṃ yugam / tasya tāvac chatī saṃdhyā saṃdhyāṃśaś ca tathāvidhaḥ //
column2: They declare that the Krita age (consists of) four thousand years (of the gods); the twilight preceding it consists of as many hundreds, and the twilight following it of the same number.

column1: itareṣu sasaṃdhyeṣu sasaṃdhyāṃśeṣu ca triṣu / ekāpāyena vartante sahasrāṇi śatāni ca //
column2: In the other three ages with their twilights preceding and following, the thousands and hundreds are diminished by one (in each).

column1: yad etat parisaṃkhyātam ādāv eva caturyugam / etad dvādaśasāhasraṃ devānāṃ yugam ucyate //
column2: These twelve thousand (years) which thus have been just mentioned as the total of four (human) ages, are called one age of the gods.

column1: daivikānāṃ yugānāṃ tu sahasraṃ parisaṃkhyayā / brāhmam ekam ahar jñeyaṃ tāvatīṃ rātrim eva ca // tad vai yugasahasrāntaṃ brāhmaṃ puṇyam ahar viduḥ / rātriṃ ca tāvatīm eva te 'horātravido janāḥ //
column2: But know that the sum of one thousand ages of the gods (makes) one day of Brahman, and that his night has the same length. column1: tasya so 'harniśasyānte prasuptaḥ pratibudhyate / pratibuddhaś ca sṛjati manaḥ sadasadātmakam //
column2: At the end of that day and night he who was asleep, awakes and, after awaking, creates mind, which is both real and unreal.

column1: yad prāg dvādaśasāhasram uditaṃ daivikaṃ yugam / tad ekasaptatiguṇaṃ manvantaram ihocyate //
column2: The before-mentioned age of the gods, (or) twelve thousand (of their years), being multiplied by seventy-one, (constitutes what) is here named the period of a Manu (Manvantara).

column1: manvantarāṇy asaṃkhyāni sargaḥ saṃhāra eva ca / krīḍann ivaitat kurute parameṣṭhī punaḥ punaḥ //
column2: The Manvantaras, the creations and destructions (of the world, are) numberless; sporting, as it were, Brahman repeats this again and again.

column1: catuṣpāt sakalo dharmaḥ satyaṃ caiva kṛte yuge / nādharmeṇāgamaḥ kaś cin manuṣyān prati vartate // itareṣv āgamād dharmaḥ pādaśas tv avaropitaḥ / caurikānṛtamāyābhir dharmaś cāpaiti pādaśaḥ //
column2: In the Krita age Dharma is four-footed and entire, and (so is) Truth; nor does any gain accrue to men by unrighteousness. In the other (three ages), by reason of (unjust) gains (agama), Dharma is deprived successively of one foot, and through (the prevalence of) theft, falsehood, and fraud the merit (gained by men) is diminished by one fourth (in each).

column1: arogāḥ sarvasiddhārthāś caturvarṣaśatāyuṣaḥ / kṛte tretādiṣu hy eṣāṃ āyur hrasati pādaśaḥ //
column2: (Men are) free from disease, accomplish all their aims, and live four hundred years in the Krita age, but in the Treta and (in each of) the succeeding (ages) their life is lessened by one quarter.

column1: vedoktam āyur martyānām āśiṣaś caiva karmaṇām / phalanty anuyugaṃ loke prabhāvaś ca śarīriṇām //
column2: The life of mortals, mentioned in the Veda, the desired results of sacrificial rites and the (supernatural) power of embodied (spirits) are fruits proportioned among men according to (the character of) the age.

column1: anye kṛtayuge dharmās tretāyāṃ dvāpare 'pare / anye kaliyuge nṝṇāṃ yugahrāsānurūpataḥ //
column2: One set of duties (is prescribed) for men in the Krita age, different ones in the Treta and in the Dvapara, and (again) another (set) in the Kali, in a proportion as (those) ages decrease in length.

column1: tapaḥ paraṃ kṛtayuge tretāyāṃ jñānam ucyate / dvāpare yajñam evāhur dānam ekaṃ kalau yuge //
column2: In the Krita age the chief (virtue) is declared to be (the performance of) austerities, in the Treta (divine) knowledge, in the Dvapara (the performance of) sacrifices, in the Kali liberality alone.

column1: sarvasyāsya tu sargasya guptyarthaṃ sa mahādyutiḥ / mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ pṛthakkarmāṇy akalpayat //
column2: But in order to protect this universe He, the most resplendent one, assigned separate (duties and) occupations to those who sprang from his mouth, arms, thighs, and feet.

column1: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā / dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat //
column2: To Brahmanas he assigned teaching and studying (the Veda), sacrificing for their own benefit and for others, giving and accepting (of alms).

column1: prajānāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānam ijyādhyayanam eva ca / viṣayeṣv aprasaktiś ca kṣatriyasya samāsataḥ //
column2: The Kshatriya he commanded to protect the people, to bestow gifts, to offer sacrifices, to study (the Veda), and to abstain from attaching himself to sensual pleasures;

column1: paśūnāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ dānam ijyādhyayanam eva ca / vaṇikpathaṃ kusīdaṃ ca vaiśyasya kṛṣim eva ca //
column2: The Vaisya to tend cattle, to bestow gifts, to offer sacrifices, to study (the Veda), to trade, to lend money, and to cultivate land.

column1: ekam eva tu śūdrasya prabhuḥ karma samādiśat / eteṣām eva varṇānāṃ śuśrūṣām anasūyayā //
column2: One occupation only the lord prescribed to the Sudra, to serve meekly even these (other) three castes.

column1: ūrdhvaṃ nābher medhyataraḥ puruṣaḥ parikīrtitaḥ / tasmān medhyatamaṃ tv asya mukham uktaṃ svayaṃbhuvā //
column2: Man is stated to be purer above the navel (than below); hence the Self-existent (Svayambhu) has declared the purest (part) of him (to be) his mouth.

column1: yasyāsyena sadāśnanti havyāni tridivaukasaḥ / kavyāni caiva pitaraḥ kiṃ bhūtam adhikaṃ tataḥ //
column2: What created being can surpass him, through whose mouth the gods continually consume the sacrificial viands and the manes the offerings to the dead?

column1: bhūtānāṃ prāṇinaḥ śreṣṭhāḥ prāṇināṃ buddhijīvinaḥ / buddhimatsu narāḥ śreṣṭhā nareṣu brāhmaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: Of created beings the most excellent are said to be those which are animated; of the animated, those which subsist by intelligence; of the intelligent, mankind; and of men, the Brahmanas;

column1: brāhmaṇeṣu ca vidvāṃso vidvatsu kṛtabuddhayaḥ / kṛtabuddhiṣu kartāraḥ kartṛṣu brahmavedinaḥ //
column2: Of Brahmanas, those learned (in the Veda); of the learned, those who recognise (the necessity and the manner of performing the prescribed duties); of those who possess this knowledge, those who perform them; of the performers, those who know the Brahman.

column1: utpattir eva viprasya mūrtir dharmasya śāśvatī / sa hi dharmārtham utpanno brahmabhūyāya kalpate //
column2: The very birth of a Brahmana is an eternal incarnation of the sacred law; for he is born to (fulfil) the sacred law, and becomes one with Brahman.

column1: brāhmaṇo jāyamāno hi pṛthivyām adhijāyate / īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ dharmakośasya guptaye //
column2: A Brahmana, coming into existence, is born as the highest on earth, the lord of all created beings, for the protection of the treasury of the law.

column1: sarvaṃ svaṃ brāhmaṇasyedaṃ yat kiṃ cij jagatīgataṃ / śraiṣṭhyenābhijanenedaṃ sarvaṃ vai brāhmaṇo 'rhati //
column2: Whatever exists in the world is, the property of the Brahmana; on account of the excellence of his origin The Brahmana is, indeed, entitled to all.

column1: svam eva brāhmaṇo bhuṅkte svaṃ vaste svaṃ dadāti ca / ānṛśaṃsyād brāhmaṇasya bhuñjate hītare janāḥ //
column2: The Brahmana eats but his own food, wears but his own apparel, bestows but his own in alms; other mortals subsist through the benevolence of the Brahmana.

column1: tasya karmavivekārthaṃ śeṣāṇām anupūrvaśaḥ / svāyaṃbhuvo manur dhīmān idaṃ śāstram akalpayat //
column2: In order to clearly settle his duties those of the other (castes) according to their order, wise Manu sprung from the Self-existent, composed these Institutes (of the sacred Law).

column1: viduṣā brāhmaṇenedam adhyetavyaṃ prayatnataḥ / śiśyebhyaś ca pravaktavyaṃ samyaṅ nānyena kena cit //
column2: A learned Brahmana must carefully study them, and he must duly instruct his pupils in them, but nobody else (shall do it).

column1: idaṃ śāstram adhīyāno brāhmaṇaḥ śaṃsitavrataḥ / manovāggehajair nityaṃ karmadoṣair na lipyate //
column2: A Brahmana who studies these Institutes (and) faithfully fulfils the duties (prescribed therein), is never tainted by sins, arising from thoughts, words, or deeds.

column1: punāti paṅktiṃ vaṃśyāṃś ca saptasapta parāvarān / pṛthivīm api caivemāṃ kṛtsnām eko 'pi so 'rhati //
column2: He sanctifies any company (which he may enter), seven ancestors and seven descendants, and he alone deserves (to possess) this whole earth.

column1: idaṃ svastyayanaṃ śreṣṭham idaṃ buddhivivardhanam / idaṃ yaśasyam āyuṣyam idaṃ niḥśreyasaṃ param //
column2: (To study) this (work) is the best means of securing welfare, it increases understanding, it procures fame and long life, it (leads to) supreme bliss.

column1: asmin dharmo 'khilenokto guṇadoṣau ca karmaṇām / caturṇām api varṇānām ācāraś caiva śāśvataḥ //
column2: In this (work) the sacred law has been fully stated as well as the good and bad qualities of (human) actions and the immemorial rule of conduct, (to be followed) by all the four castes (varna).

column1: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca / tasmād asmin sadā yukto nityaṃ syād ātmavān dvijaḥ //
column2: The rule of conduct is transcendent law, whether it be taught in the revealed texts or in the sacred tradition; hence a twice-born man who possesses regard for himself, should be always careful to (follow) it.

column1: ācārād vicyuto vipro na vedaphalam aśnute / ācāreṇa tu saṃyuktaḥ sampūrṇaphalabhāj bhavet //
column2: A Brahmana who departs from the rule of conduct, does not reap the fruit of the Veda, but he who duly follows it, will obtain the full reward.

column1: evam ācārato dṛṣṭvā dharmasya munayo gatiṃ / sarvasya tapaso mūlam ācāraṃ jagṛhuḥ param //
column2: The sages who saw that the sacred law is thus grounded on the rule of conduct, have taken good conduct to be the most excellent root of all austerity.

column1: jagataś ca samutpattiṃ saṃskāravidhim eva ca / vratacaryopacāraṃ ca snānasya ca paraṃ vidhim //
column2: The creation of the universe, the rule of the sacraments, the ordinances of studentship, and the respectful behaviour (towards Gurus), the most excellent rule of bathing (on return from the teacher's house),

column1: dārādhigamanaṃ caiva vivāhānāṃ ca lakṣaṇam / mahāyajñavidhānaṃ ca śrāddhakalpaṃ ca śāśvatam //
column2: (The law of) marriage and the description of the (various) marriage-rites, the regulations for the great sacrifices and the eternal rule of the funeral sacrifices,

column1: vṛttīnāṃ lakṣaṇaṃ caiva snātakasya vratāni ca / bhakṣyābhakṣyaṃ ca śaucaṃ ca dravyāṇāṃ śuddhim eva ca //
column2: The description of the modes of (gaining) subsistence and the duties of a Snataka, (the rules regarding) lawful and forbidden food, the purification of men and of things,

column1: strīdharmayogaṃ tāpasyaṃ mokṣaṃ saṃnyāsam eva ca / rājñaś ca dharmam akhilaṃ kāryāṇāṃ ca vinirṇayam //
column2: The laws concerning women, (the law) of hermits, (the manner of gaining) final emancipation and (of) renouncing the world, the whole duty of a king and the manner of deciding lawsuits,

column1: sākṣipraśnavidhānaṃ ca dharmaṃ strīpuṃsayor api / vibhāgadharmaṃ dyūtaṃ ca kaṇṭakānāṃ ca śodhanam // vaiśyaśūdropacāraṃ ca saṃkīrṇānāṃ ca saṃbhavam / āpaddharmaṃ ca varṇānāṃ prāyaścittavidhiṃ tathā //
column2: The rules for the examination of witnesses, the laws concerning husband and wife, the law of (inheritance and) division, (the law concerning) gambling and the removal of (men nocuous like) thorns, (The law concerning) the behaviour of Vaisyas and Sudras, the origin of the mixed castes, the law for all castes in times of distress and the law of penances,

column1: saṃsāragamanaṃ caiva trividhaṃ karmasaṃbhavam / niḥśreyasaṃ karmaṇāṃ ca guṇadoṣaparīkṣaṇam //
column2: The threefold course of transmigrations, the result of (good or bad) actions, (the manner of attaining) supreme bliss and the examination of the good and bad qualities of actions,

column1: deśadharmāñ jātidharmān kuladharmāṃś ca śāśvatān / pāṣaṇḍagaṇadharmāṃś ca śāstre 'sminn uktavān manuḥ //
column2: The primeval laws of countries, of castes (gati), of families, and the rules concerning heretics and companies (of traders and the like)- (all that) Manu has declared in these Institutes.

column1: yathedam uktavāñ śāstraṃ purā pṛṣṭo manur mayā / tathedaṃ yūyam apy adya matsakāśān nibodhata //
column2: As Manu, in reply to my questions, formerly promulgated these Institutes, even so learn ye also the (whole work) from me.

column1: vidvadbhiḥ sevitaḥ sadbhir nityam adveṣarāgibhiḥ / hṛdayenābhyanujñāto yo dharmas taṃ nibodhata //
column2: Learn that sacred law which is followed by men learned (in the Veda) and assented to in their hearts by the virtuous, who are ever exempt from hatred and inordinate affection.

column1: kāmātmatā na praśastā na caivehāsty akāmatā / kāmyo hi vedādhigamaḥ karmayogaś ca vaidikaḥ //
column2: To act solely from a desire for rewards is not laudable, yet an exemption from that desire is not (to be found) in this (world): for on (that) desire is grounded the study of the Veda and the performance of the actions, prescribed by the Veda.

column1: saṃkalpamūlaḥ kāmo vai yajñāḥ saṃkalpasaṃbhavāḥ / vratāni yamadharmāś ca sarve saṃkalpajāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: The desire (for rewards), indeed, has its root in the conception that an act can yield them, and in consequence of (that) conception sacrifices are performed; vows and the laws prescribing restraints are all stated to be kept through the idea that they will bear fruit.

column1: akāmasya kriyā kā cid dṛśyate neha karhi cit / yad yad dhi kurute kiṃ cit tat tat kāmasya ceṣṭitam //
column2: Not a single act here (below) appears ever to be done by a man free from desire; for whatever (man) does, it is (the result of) the impulse of desire.

column1: teṣu samyag vartamāno gacchaty amaralokatām / yathā saṃkalpitāṃś ceha sarvān kāmān samaśnute //
column2: He who persists in discharging these (prescribed duties) in the right manner, reaches the deathless state and even in this (life) obtains (the fulfilment of) all the desires that he may have conceived.

column1: vedo 'khilo dharmamūlaṃ smṛtiśīle ca tadvidām / ācāraś caiva sādhūnām ātmanas tuṣṭir eva ca //
column2: The whole Veda is the (first) source of the sacred law, next the tradition and the virtuous conduct of those who know the (Veda further), also the customs of holy men, and (finally) self-satisfaction.

column1: yaḥ kaś cit kasya cid dharmo manunā parikīrtitaḥ / sa sarvo 'bhihito vede sarvajñānamayo hi saḥ //
column2: Whatever law has been ordained for any (person) by Manu, that has been fully declared in the Veda: for that (sage was) omniscient.

column1: sarvaṃ tu samavekṣyedaṃ nikhilaṃ jñānacakṣuṣā / śrutiprāmāṇyato vidvān svadharme niviśeta vai //
column2: But a learned man after fully scrutinising all this with the eye of knowledge, should, in accordance with the authority of the revealed texts, be intent on (the performance of) his duties.

column1: śrutismṛtyuditaṃ dharmam anutiṣṭhan hi mānavaḥ / iha kīrtim avāpnoti pretya cānuttamaṃ sukham //
column2: For that man who obeys the law prescribed in the revealed texts and in the sacred tradition, gains fame in this (world) and after death unsurpassable bliss.

column1: śrutis tu vedo vijñeyo dharmaśāstraṃ tu vai smṛtiḥ / te sarvārtheṣv amīmāṃsye tābhyāṃ dharmo hi nirbabhau // yo 'vamanyeta te mūle hetuśāstrāśrayād dvijaḥ / sa sādhubhir bahiṣkāryo nāstiko vedanindakaḥ //
column2: But by Sruti (revelation) is meant the Veda, and by Smriti (tradition) the Institutes of the sacred law: those two must not be called into question in any matter, since from those two the sacred law shone forth. Every twice-born man, who, relying on the Institutes of dialectics, treats with contempt those two sources (of the law), must be cast out by the virtuous, as an atheist and a scorner of the Veda.

column1: vedaḥ smṛtiḥ sadācāraḥ svasya ca priyam ātmanaḥ / etac caturvidhaṃ prāhuḥ sākṣād dharmasya lakṣaṇam //
column2: The Veda, the sacred tradition, the customs of virtuous men, and one's own pleasure, they declare to be visibly the fourfold means of defining the sacred law.

column1: arthakāmeṣv asaktānāṃ dharmajñānaṃ vidhīyate / dharmaṃ jijñāsamānānāṃ pramāṇaṃ paramaṃ śrutiḥ //
column2: The knowledge of the sacred law is prescribed for those who are not given to the acquisition of wealth and to the gratification of their desires; to those who seek the knowledge of the sacred law the supreme authority is the revelation (Sruti).

column1: śrutidvaidhaṃ tu yatra syāt tatra dharmāv ubhau smṛtau / ubhāv api hi tau dharmau samyag uktau manīṣibhiḥ //
column2: But when two sacred texts (Sruti) are conflicting, both are held to be law; for both are pronounced by the wise (to be) valid law.

column1: udite 'nudite caiva samayādhyuṣite tathā / sarvathā vartate yajña itīyaṃ vaidikī śrutiḥ //
column2: (Thus) the (Agnihotra) sacrifice may be (optionally) performed, at any time after the sun has risen, before he has risen, or when neither sun nor stars are visible; that (is declared) by Vedic texts.

column1: niṣekādiśmaśānānto mantrair yasyodito vidhiḥ / tasya śāstre 'dhikāro 'smiñ jñeyo nānyasya kasya cit //
column2: Know that he for whom (the performance of) the ceremonies beginning with the rite of impregnation (Garbhadhana) and ending with the funeral rite (Antyeshti) is prescribed, while sacred formulas are being recited, is entitled (to study) these Institutes, but no other man whatsoever.

column1: sarasvatīdṛśadvatyor devanadyor yad antaram / taṃ devanirmitaṃ deśaṃ brahmāvartaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: That land, created by the gods, which lies between the two divine rivers Sarasvati and Drishadvati, the (sages) call Brahmavarta.

column1: tasmin deśe ya ācāraḥ pāramparyakramāgataḥ / varṇānāṃ sāntarālānāṃ sa sadācāra ucyate //
column2: The custom handed down in regular succession (since time immemorial) among the (four chief) castes (varna) and the mixed (races) of that country, is called the conduct of virtuous men.

column1: kurukṣetraṃ ca matsyāś ca pañcālāḥ śūrasenakāḥ / eṣa brahmarṣideśo vai brahmāvartād anantaraḥ //
column2: The plain of the Kurus, the (country of the) Matsyas, Pankalas, and Surasenakas, these (form), indeed, the country of the Brahmarshis (Brahmanical sages, which ranks) immediately after Brahmavarta.

column1: etad deśaprasūtasya sakāśād agrajanmanaḥ / svaṃ svaṃ caritraṃ śikṣeran pṛthivyāṃ sarvamānavāḥ //
column2: From a Brahmana, born in that country, let all men on earth learn their several usages.

column1: himavadvindhyayor madhyaṃ yat prāg vinaśanād api / pratyag eva prayāgāc ca madhyadeśaḥ prakīrtitaḥ //
column2: That (country) which (lies) between the Himavat and the Vindhya (mountains) to the east of Prayaga and to the west of Vinasana (the place where the river Sarasvati disappears) is called Madhyadesa (the central region).

column1: ā samudrāt tu vai pūrvād ā samudrāc ca paścimāt / tayor evāntaraṃ giryor āryāvartaṃ vidur budhāḥ //
column2: But (the tract) between those two mountains (just mentioned), which (extends) as far as the eastern and the western oceans, the wise call Aryavarta (the country of the Aryans).

column1: kṛṣṇasāras tu carati mṛgo yatra svabhāvataḥ / sa jñeyo yajñiyo deśo mlecchadeśas tv ataḥ paraḥ //
column2: That land where the black antelope naturally roams, one must know to be fit for the performance of sacrifices; (the tract) different from that (is) the country of the Mlekkhas (barbarians).

column1: etāṇ dvijātayo deśān saṃśrayeran prayatnataḥ / śūdras tu yasmin kasmin vā nivased vṛttikarśitaḥ //
column2: Let twice-born men seek to dwell in those (above-mentioned countries); but a Sudra, distressed for subsistence, may reside anywhere.

column1: eṣā dharmasya vo yoniḥ samāsena prakīrtitā / saṃbhavaś cāsya sarvasya varṇadharmān nibodhata //
column2: Thus has the origin of the sacred law been succinctly described to you and the origin of this universe; learn (now) the duties of the castes (varna).

column1: vaidikaiḥ karmabhiḥ puṇyair niṣekādir dvijanmanām / kāryaḥ śarīrasaṃskāraḥ pāvanaḥ pretya ceha ca //
column2: With holy rites, prescribed by the Veda, must the ceremony on conception and other sacraments be performed for twice-born men, which sanctify the body and purify (from sin) in this (life) and after death.

column1: gārbhair homair jātakarma- cauḍamauñjīnibandhanaiḥ / baijikaṃ gārbhikaṃ caino dvijānām apamṛjyate //
column2: By burnt oblations during (the mother's) pregnancy, by the Gatakarman (the ceremony after birth), the Kauda (tonsure), and the Maungibandhana (the tying of the sacred girdle of Munga grass) is the taint, derived from both parents, removed from twice-born men.

column1: svādhyāyena vratair homais traividyenejyayā sutaiḥ / mahāyajñaiś ca yajñaiś ca brāhmīyaṃ kriyate tanuḥ //
column2: By the study of the Veda, by vows, by burnt oblations, by (the recitation of) sacred texts, by the (acquisition of the) threefold sacred science, by offering (to the gods, Rishis, and manes), by (the procreation of) sons, by the great sacrifices, and by (Srauta) rites this (human) body is made fit for (union with) Brahman.

column1: prāṅ nābhivardhanāt puṃso jātakarma vidhīyate / mantravat prāśanaṃ cāsya hiraṇyamadhusarpiṣām //
column2: Before the navel-string is cut, the Gatakarman (birth-rite) must be performed for a male (child); and while sacred formulas are being recited, he must be fed with gold, honey, and butter.

column1: nāmadheyaṃ daśamyāṃ tu dvādaśyāṃ vāsya kārayet / puṇye tithau muhūrte vā nakṣatre vā guṇānvite //
column2: But let (the father perform or) cause to be performed the Namadheya (the rite of naming the child), on the tenth or twelfth (day after birth), or on a lucky lunar day, in a lucky muhurta, under an auspicious constellation.

column1: maṅgalyaṃ brāhmaṇasya syāt kṣatriyasya balānvitam / vaiśyasya dhanasaṃyuktaṃ śūdrasya tu jugupsitam // śarmavad brāhmaṇasya syād rājño rakṣāsamanvitam / vaiśyasya puṣṭisaṃyuktaṃ śūdrasya preṣyasaṃyutam //
column2: Let (the first part of) a Brahmana's name (denote something) auspicious, a Kshatriya's be connected with power, and a Vaisya's with wealth, but a Sudra's (express something) contemptible. (The second part of) a Brahmana's (name) shall be (a word) implying happiness, of a Kshatriya's (a word) implying protection, of a Vaisya's (a term) expressive of thriving, and of a Sudra's (an expression) denoting service.

column1: strīṇāṃ sukhodyam akrūraṃ vispaṣṭārthaṃ manoharam / maṅgalyaṃ dīrghavarṇāntam āśīrvādābhidhānavat //
column2: The names of women should be easy to pronounce, not imply anything dreadful, possess a plain meaning, be pleasing and auspicious, end in long vowels, and contain a word of benediction.

column1: caturthe māsi kartavyaṃ śiśor niṣkramaṇaṃ gṛhāt / ṣaṣṭhe 'nnaprāśanaṃ māsi yad veṣṭaṃ maṅgalaṃ kule //
column2: In the fourth month the Nishkramana (the first leaving of the house) of the child should be performed, in the sixth month the Annaprasana (first feeding with rice), and optionally (any other) auspicious ceremony required by (the custom of) the family.

column1: cūḍākarma dvijātīnāṃ sarveṣām eva dharmataḥ / prathame 'bde tṛtīye vā kartavyaṃ śruticodanāt //
column2: According to the teaching of the revealed texts, the Kudakarman (tonsure) must be performed, for the sake of spiritual merit, by all twice-born men in the first or third year.

column1: garbhāṣṭame 'bde kurvīta brāhmaṇasyopanāyanam / garbhād ekādaśe rājño garbhāt tu dvādaśe viśaḥ //
column2: In the eighth year after conception, one should perform the initiation (upanayana) of a Brahmana, in the eleventh after conception (that) of a Kshatriya, but in the twelfth that of a Vaisya.

column1: brahmavarcasakāmasya kāryo viprasya pañcame / rājño balārthinaḥ ṣaṣṭhe vaiśyasyehārthino 'ṣṭame //
column2: (The initiation) of a Brahmana who desires proficiency in sacred learning should take place in the fifth (year after conception), (that) of a Kshatriya who wishes to become powerful in the sixth, (and that) of a Vaisya who longs for (success in his) business in the eighth.

column1: ā ṣodaśād brāhmaṇasya sāvitrī nātivartate / ā dvāviṃśāt kṣatrabandhor ā caturviṃśater viśaḥ //
column2: The (time for the) Savitri (initiation) of a Brahmana does not pass until the completion of the sixteenth year (after conception), of a Kshatriya until the completion of the twenty-second, and of a Vaisya until the completion of the twenty-fourth.

column1: ata ūrdhvaṃ trayo 'py ete yathākālam asaṃskṛtāḥ / sāvitrīpatitā vrātyā bhavanty āryavigarhitāḥ //
column2: After those (periods men of) these three (castes) who have not received the sacrament at the proper time, become Vratyas (outcasts), excluded from the Savitri (initiation) and despised by the Aryans.

column1: naitair apūtair vidhivad āpady api hi karhi cit / brāhmān yaunāṃś ca saṃbandhān nācared brāhmaṇaḥ saha //
column2: With such men, if they have not been purified according to the rule, let no Brahmana ever, even in times of distress, form a connexion either through the Veda or by marriage.

column1: kārṣṇarauravabāstāni carmāṇi brahmacāriṇaḥ / vasīrann ānupūrvyeṇa śāṇakṣaumāvikāni ca //
column2: Let students, according to the order (of their castes), wear (as upper dresses) the skins of black antelopes, spotted deer, and he-goats, and (lower garments) made of hemp, flax or wool.

column1: mauñjī trivṛt samā ślakṣṇā kāryā viprasya mekhalā / kṣatriyasya tu maurvī jyā vaiśyasya śaṇatāntavī //
column2: The girdle of a Brahmana shall consist of a of a triple cord of Munga grass, smooth and soft; (that) of a Kshatriya, of a bowstring, made of Murva fibres; (that) of a Vaisya, of hempen threads.

column1: muñjālābhe tu kartavyāḥ kuśāśmantakabalvajaiḥ / trivṛtā granthinaikena tribhiḥ pañcabhir eva vā //
column2: If Munga grass (and so forth) be not procurable, (the girdles) may be made of Kusa, Asmantaka, and Balbaga (fibres), with a single threefold knot, or with three or five (knots according to the custom of the family).

column1: kārpāsam upavītaṃ syād viprasyordhvavṛtaṃ trivṛt / śaṇasūtramayaṃ rājño vaiśyasyāvikasautrikam //
column2: The sacrificial string of a Brahmana shall be made of cotton, (shall be) twisted to the right, (and consist) of three threads, that of a Kshatriya of hempen threads, (and) that of a Vaisya of woollen threads.

column1: brāhmaṇo bailvapālāśau kṣatriyo vāṭakhādirau / pailavāudumbarau vaiśyo daṇḍān arhanti dharmataḥ //
column2: A Brahmana shall (carry), according to the sacred law, a staff of Bilva or Palasa; a Kshatriya, of Vata or Khadira; (and) a Vaisya, of Pilu or Udumbara.

column1: keśāntiko brāhmaṇasya daṇḍaḥ kāryaḥ pramāṇataḥ / lalāṭasammito rājñaḥ syāt tu nāsāntiko viśaḥ //
column2: The staff of a Brahmana shall be made of such length as to reach the end of his hair; that of a Kshatriya, to reach his forehead;(and) that of a Vaisya, to reach (the tip of his) nose.

column1: ṛjavas te tu sarve syur avraṇāḥ saumyadarśanāḥ / anudvegakarā nṝṇāṃ satvaco 'nagnidūṣitāḥ //
column2: Let all the staves be straight, without a blemish, handsome to look at, not likely to terrify men, with their bark perfect, unhurt by fire.

column1: pratigṛhyepsitaṃ daṇḍam upasthāya ca bhāskaram / pradakṣiṇaṃ parītyāgniṃ cared bhaikṣaṃ yathāvidhi //
column2: Having taken a staff according to his choice, having worshipped the sun and walked round the fire, turning his right hand towards it, (the student) should beg alms according to the prescribed rule.

column1: bhavatpūrvaṃ cared bhaikṣam upanīto dvijottamaḥ / bhavanmadhyaṃ tu rājanyo vaiśyas tu bhavaduttaram //
column2: An initiated Brahmana should beg, beginning (his request with the word) lady (bhavati); a Kshatriya, placing (the word) lady in the middle, but a Vaisya, placing it at the end (of the formula).

column1: mātaraṃ vā svasāraṃ vā mātur vā bhaginīṃ nijām / bhikṣeta bhikṣāṃ prathamaṃ yā cainaṃ nāvamānayet //
column2: Let him first beg food of his mother, or of his sister, or of his own maternal aunt, or of (some other) female who will not disgrace him (by a refusal).

column1: samāhṛtya tu tad bhaikṣaṃ yāvadannam amāyayā / nivedya gurave 'śnīyād ācamya prāṅmukhaḥ śuciḥ //
column2: Having collected as much food as is required (from several persons), and having announced it without guile to his teacher, let him eat, turning his face towards the east, and having purified himself by sipping water.

column1: āyuṣyaṃ prāṅmukho bhuṅkte yaśasyaṃ dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ / śriyaṃ pratyaṅmukho bhuṅkte ṛtaṃ bhuṅkte hy udaṅmukhaḥ //
column2: (His meal will procure) long life, if he eats facing the east; fame, if he turns to the south; prosperity, if he turns to the west; truthfulness, if he faces the east.

column1: upaspṛśya dvijo nityam annam adyāt samāhitaḥ / bhuktvā copaspṛśet samyag adbhiḥ khāni ca saṃspṛśet //
column2: Let a twice-born man always eat his food with concentrated mind, after performing an ablution; and after he has eaten, let him duly cleanse himself with water and sprinkle the cavities (of his head).

column1: pūjayed aśanaṃ nityam adyāc caitad akutsayan / dṛṣṭvā hṛṣyet prasīdec ca pratinandec ca sarvaśaḥ //
column2: Let him always worship his food, and eat it without contempt; when he sees it, let him rejoice, show a pleased face, and pray that he may always obtain it.

column1: pūjitaṃ hy aśanaṃ nityaṃ balam ūrjaṃ ca yacchati / apūjitaṃ tu tad bhuktam ubhayaṃ nāśayed idam //
column2: Food, that is always worshipped, gives strength and manly vigour; but eaten irreverently, it destroys them both.

column1: nocchiṣṭaṃ kasya cid dadyān nādyād etat tathāntarā / na caivātyaśanaṃ kuryān na cocchiṣṭaḥ kva cid vrajet //
column2: Let him not give to any man what he leaves, and beware of eating between (the two meal-times); let him not over-eat himself, nor go anywhere without having purified himself (after his meal).

column1: anārogyam anāyuṣyam asvargyaṃ cātibhojanam / apuṇyaṃ lokavidviṣṭaṃ tasmāt tat parivarjayet //
column2: Excessive eating is prejudicial to health, to fame, and to (bliss in) heaven; it prevents (the acquisition of) spiritual merit, and is odious among men; one ought, for these reasons, to avoid it carefully.

column1: brāhmeṇa vipras tīrthena nityakālam upaspṛśet / kāyatraidaśikābhyāṃ vā na pitryeṇa kadā cana //
column2: Let a Brahmana always sip water out of the part of the hand (tirtha) sacred to Brahman, or out of that sacred to Ka (Pragapati), or out of (that) sacred to the gods, never out of that sacred to the manes.

column1: aṅguṣṭhamūlasya tale brāhmaṃ tīrthaṃ pracakṣate / kāyam aṅgulimūle 'gre devaṃ pitryaṃ tayor adhaḥ //
column2: They call (the part) at the root of the thumb the tirtha sacred to Brahman, that at the root of the (little) finger (the tirtha) sacred to Ka (Pragapati), (that) at the tips (of the fingers, the tirtha) sacred to the gods, and that below (between the index and the thumb, the tirtha) sacred to the manes.

column1: trir ācāmed apaḥ pūrvaṃ dviḥ pramṛjyāt tato mukham / khāni caiva spṛśed adbhir ātmānaṃ śira eva ca //
column2: Let him first sip water thrice; next twice wipe his mouth; and, lastly, touch with water the cavities (of the head), (the seat of) the soul and the head.

column1: anuṣṇābhir aphenābhir adbhis tīrthena dharmavit / śaucepsuḥ sarvadācāmed ekānte prāgudaṅmukhaḥ //
column2: He who knows the sacred law and seeks purity shall always perform the rite of sipping with water neither hot nor frothy, with the (prescribed) tirtha, in a lonely place, and turning to the east or to the north.

column1: hṛdgābhiḥ pūyate vipraḥ kaṇṭhagābhis tu bhūmipaḥ / vaiśyo 'dbhiḥ prāśitābhis tu śūdraḥ spṛṣṭābhir antataḥ //
column2: A Brahmana is purified by water that reaches his heart, a Kshatriya by water reaching his throat, a Vaisya by water taken into his mouth, (and) a Sudra by water touched with the extremity (of his lips).

column1: uddhṛte dakṣine pāṇāv upavīty ucyate dvijaḥ / savye prācīnāvītī nivītī kaṇṭhasajjane //
column2: A twice-born man is called upavitin when his right arm is raised (and the sacrificial string or the dress, passed under it, rests on the left shoulder); (when his) left (arm) is raised (and the string, or the dress, passed under it, rests on the right shoulder, he is called) prakinavitin; and nivitin when it hangs down (straight) from the neck.

column1: mekhalām ajinaṃ daṇḍam upavītaṃ kamaṇḍalum / apsu prāsya vinaṣṭāni gṛhṇītānyāni mantravat //
column2: His girdle, the skin (which serves as his upper garment), his staff, his sacrificial thread, (and) his water-pot he must throw into water, when they have been damaged, and take others, reciting sacred formulas.

column1: keśāntaḥ ṣoḍaśe varṣe brāhmaṇasya vidhīyate / rājanyabandhor dvāviṃśe vaiśyasya dvyadhike mataḥ //
column2: (The ceremony called) Kesanta (clipping the hair) is ordained for a Brahmana in the sixteenth year (from conception); for a Kshatriya, in the twenty-second; and for a Vaisya, two (years) later than that.

column1: amantrikā tu kāryeyaṃ strīṇām āvṛd aśeṣataḥ / saṃskārārthaṃ śarīrasya yathākālaṃ yathākramam //
column2: This whole series (of ceremonies) must be performed for females (also), in order to sanctify the body, at the proper time and in the proper order, but without (the recitation of) sacred texts.

column1: vaivāhiko vidhiḥ strīṇāṃ saṃskāro vaidikaḥ smṛtaḥ / patisevā gurau vāso gṛhārtho 'gniparikriyā //
column2: The nuptial ceremony is stated to be the Vedic sacrament for women (and to be equal to the initiation), serving the husband (equivalent to) the residence in (the house of the) teacher, and the household duties (the same) as the (daily) worship of the sacred fire.

column1: eṣa prokto dvijātīnām aupanāyaniko vidhiḥ / utpattivyañjakaḥ puṇyaḥ karmayogaṃ nibodhata //
column2: Thus has been described the rule for the initiation of the twice-born, which indicates a (new) birth, and sanctifies; learn (now) to what duties they must afterwards apply themselves.

column1: upanīya guruḥ śiṣyaṃ śikṣayec chaucam āditaḥ / ācāram agnikāryaṃ ca saṃdhyopāsanam eva ca //
column2: Having performed the (rite of) initiation, the teacher must first instruct the (pupil) in (the rules of) personal purification, of conduct, of the fire-worship, and of the twilight devotions.

column1: adhyeṣyamāṇas tv ācānto yathāśāstram udaṅmukhaḥ / brahmāñjalikṛto 'dhyāpyo laghuvāsā jitendriyaḥ //
column2: But (a student) who is about to begin the Study (of the Veda), shall receive instruction, after he has sipped water in accordance with the Institutes (of the sacred law), has made the Brahmangali, (has put on) a clean dress, and has brought his organs under due control.

column1: brahmārambhe 'vasāne ca pādau grāhyau guroḥ sadā / saṃhatya hastāv adhyeyaṃ sa hi brahmāñjaliḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: At the beginning and at the end of (a lesson in the) Veda he must always clasp both the feet of his teacher, (and) he must study, joining his hands; that is called the Brahmangali (joining the palms for the sake of the Veda).

column1: vyatyastapāṇinā kāryam upasaṃgrahaṇaṃ guroḥ / savyena savyaḥ spraṣṭavyo dakṣiṇena ca dakṣiṇaḥ //
column2: With crossed hands he must clasp (the feet) of the teacher, and touch the left (foot) with his left (hand), the right (foot) with his right (hand).

column1: adhyeṣyamāṇaṃ tu gurur nityakālam atandritaḥ / adhīṣva bho iti brūyād virāmo 'stv iti cāramet //
column2: But to him who is about to begin studying, the teacher always unwearied, must say: Ho, recite! He shall leave off (when the teacher says): Let a stoppage take place!

column1: brahmanaḥ praṇavaṃ kuryād ādāv ante ca sarvadā / sravaty anoṃkṛtaṃ pūrvaṃ parastāc ca viśīryati //
column2: Let him always pronounce the syllable Om at the beginning and at the end of (a lesson in) the Veda; (for) unless the syllable Om precede (the lesson) will slip away (from him), and unless it follow it will fade away.

column1: prākkūlān paryupāsīnaḥ pavitraiś caiva pāvitaḥ / prāṇāyāmais tribhiḥ pūtas tata oṃkāram arhati //
column2: Seated on (blades of Kusa grass) with their points to the east, purified by Pavitras (blades of Kusa grass), and sanctified by three suppressions of the breath (Pranayama), he is worthy (to pronounce) the syllable Om.

column1: akāraṃ cāpy ukāraṃ ca makāraṃ ca prajāpatiḥ / vedatrayān niraduhad bhūr bhuvaḥ svar itīti ca //
column2: Pragapati (the lord of creatures) milked out (as it were) from the three Vedas the sounds A, U, and M, and (the Vyahritis) Bhuh, Bhuvah, Svah.

column1: tribhya eva tu vedebhyaḥ pādaṃ pādam adūduhat / tad ity ṛco 'syāḥ sāvitryāḥ parameṣṭhī prajāpatiḥ //
column2: Moreover from the three Vedas Pragapati, who dwells in the highest heaven (Parameshthin), milked out (as it were) that Rik-verse, sacred to Savitri (Savitri), which begins with the word tad, one foot from each.

column1: etad akṣaram etāṃ ca japan vyāhṛtipūrvikām / saṃdhyayor vedavid vipro vedapuṇyena yujyate //
column2: A Brahmana, learned in the Veda, who recites during both twilights that syllable and that (verse), preceded by the Vyahritis, gains the (whole) merit which (the recitation of) the Vedas confers.

column1: sahasrakṛtvas tv abhyasya bahir etat trikaṃ dvijaḥ / mahato 'py enaso māsāt tvacevāhir vimucyate //
column2: A twice-born man who (daily) repeats those three one thousand times outside (the village), will be freed after a month even from great guilt, as a snake from its slough.

column1: etayā rcā visaṃyuktaḥ kāle ca kriyayā svayā / brahmakṣatriyaviśyonir garhaṇāṃ yāti sādhuṣu //
column2: The Brahmana, the Kshatriya, and the Vaisya who neglect (the recitation of) that Rik-verse and the timely (performance of the) rites (prescribed for) them, will be blamed among virtuous men.

column1: oṃkārapūrvikās tisro mahāvyāhṛtayo 'vyayāḥ / tripadā caiva sāvitrī vijñeyaṃ brahmaṇo mukham //
column2: Know that the three imperishable Mahavyahritis, preceded by the syllable Om, and (followed) by the three-footed Savitri are the portal of the Veda and the gate leading (to union with) Brahman.

column1: yo 'dhīte 'hany ahany etāṃ trīṇi varṣāṇy atandritaḥ / sa brahma param abhyeti vāyubhūtaḥ khamūrtimān //
column2: He who daily recites that (verse), untired, during three years, will enter (after death) the highest Brahman, move as free as air, and assume an ethereal form.

column1: ekākṣaraṃ paraṃ brahma prāṇāyāmaḥ paraṃ tapaḥ / sāvitryās tu paraṃ nāsti maunāt satyaṃ viśiṣyate //
column2: The monosyllable (Om) is the highest Brahman, (three) suppressions of the breath are the best (form of) austerity, but nothing surpasses the Savitri truthfulness is better than silence.

column1: kṣaranti sarvā vaidikyo juhotiyajatikriyāḥ / akṣaraṃ duṣkaraṃ jñeyaṃ brahma caiva prajāpatiḥ //
column2: All rites ordained in the Veda, burnt oblations and (other) sacrifices, pass away; but know that the syllable (Om) is imperishable, and (it is) Brahman, (and) the Lord of creatures (Pragapati).

column1: vidhiyajñāj japayajño viśiṣṭo daśabhir guṇaiḥ / upāṃśuḥ syāc chataguṇaḥ sāhasro mānasaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: An offering, consisting of muttered prayers, is ten times more efficacious than a sacrifice performed according to the rules (of the Veda); a (prayer) which is inaudible (to others) surpasses it a hundred times, and the mental (recitation of sacred texts) a thousand times.

column1: ye pākayajñās catvāro vidhiyajñasamanvitāḥ / sarve te japayajñasya kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm //
column2: The four Pakayagnas and those sacrifices which are enjoined by the rules (of the Veda) are all together not equal in value to a sixteenth part of the sacrifice consisting of muttered prayers.

column1: japyenaiva tu saṃsidhyed brāhmaṇo nātra saṃśayaḥ / kuryād anyan na vā kuryān maitro brāhmaṇa ucyate //
column2: But, undoubtedly, a Brahmana reaches the highest goal by muttering prayers only; (whether) he perform other (rites) or neglect them, he who befriends (all creatures) is declared (to be) a (true) Brahmana.

column1: indriyāṇāṃ vicaratāṃ viṣayeṣv apahāriṣu / saṃyame yatnam ātiṣṭhed vidvān yanteva vājinām //
column2: A wise man should strive to restrain his organs which run wild among alluring sensual objects, like a charioteer his horses.

column1: ekādaśendriyāṇy āhur yāni pūrve manīṣiṇaḥ / tāni samyak pravakṣyāmi yathāvad anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: Those eleven organs which former sages have named, I will properly (and) precisely enumerate in due order,

column1: śrotraṃ tvak cakṣuṣī jihvā nāsikā caiva pañcamī / pāyūpasthaṃ hastapādaṃ vāk caiva daśamī smṛtā //
column2: (Viz.) the ear, the skin, the eyes, the tongue, and the nose as the fifth, the anus, the organ of generation, hands and feet, and the (organ of) speech, named as the tenth.

column1: buddhīndriyāṇi pañcaiṣāṃ śrotrādīny anupūrvaśaḥ / karmendriyāṇi pañcaiṣāṃ pāyvādīni pracakṣate //
column2: Five of them, the ear and the rest according to their order, they call organs of sense, and five of them, the anus and the rest, organs of action.

column1: ekādaśaṃ mano jñeyaṃ svaguṇenobhayātmakam / yasmin jite jitāv etau bhavataḥ pañcakau gaṇau //
column2: Know that the internal organ (manas) is the eleventh, which by its quality belongs to both (sets); when that has been subdued, both those sets of five have been conquered.

column1: indriyāṇāṃ prasaṅgena doṣam ṛcchaty asaṃśayam / saṃniyamya tu tāny eva tataḥ siddhiṃ nigacchati //
column2: Through the attachment of his organs (to sensual pleasure) a man doubtlessly will incur guilt; but if he keep them under complete control, he will obtain success (in gaining all his aims).

column1: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāmyati / haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmeva bhūya evābhivardhate //
column2: Desire is never extinguished by the enjoyment of desired objects; it only grows stronger like a fire (fed) with clarified butter.

column1: yaś caitān prāpnuyāt sarvān yaś caitān kevalāṃs tyajet / prāpaṇāt sarvakāmānāṃ parityāgo viśiṣyate //
column2: If one man should obtain all those (sensual enjoyments) and another should renounce them all, the renunciation of all pleasure is far better than the attainment of them.

column1: na tathaitāni śakyante saṃniyantum asevayā / viṣayeṣu prajuṣṭāni yathā jñānena nityaśaḥ //
column2: Those (organs) which are strongly attached to sensual pleasures, cannot so effectually be restrained by abstinence (from enjoyments) as by a constant (pursuit of true) knowledge.

column1: vedās tyāgaś ca yajñāś ca niyamāś ca tapāṃsi ca / na vipraduṣṭabhāvasya siddhiṃ gacchati karhi cit //
column2: Neither (the study of) the Vedas, nor liberality, nor sacrifices, nor any (self-imposed) restraint, nor austerities, ever procure the attainment (of rewards) to a man whose heart is contaminated (by sensuality).

column1: śrutvā spṛṣṭvā ca dṛṣṭvā ca bhuktvā ghrātvā ca yo naraḥ / na hṛṣyati glāyati vā sa vijñeyo jitendriyaḥ //
column2: That man may be considered to have (really) subdued his organs, who on hearing and touching and seeing, on tasting and smelling (anything) neither rejoices nor repines.

column1: indriyāṇāṃ tu sarveṣāṃ yady ekaṃ kṣaratīndriyam / tenāsya kṣarati prajñā dṛteḥ pādād ivodakam //
column2: But when one among all the organs slips away (from control), thereby (man's) wisdom slips away from him, even as the water (flows) through the one (open) foot of a (water-carrier's) skin.

column1: vaśe kṛtvendriyagrāmaṃ saṃyamya ca manas tathā / sarvān saṃsādhayed arthān akṣiṇvan yogatas tanum //
column2: If he keeps all the (ten) organs as well as the mind in subjection, he may gain all his aims, without reducing his body by (the practice) of Yoga.

column1: pūrvāṃ saṃdhyāṃ japāṃs tiṣṭhet sāvitrīm ārkadarśanāt / paścimāṃ tu samāsīnaḥ samyag ṛkṣavibhāvanāt //
column2: Let him stand during the morning twilight, muttering the Savitri until the sun appears, but (let him recite it), seated, in the evening until the constellations can be seen distinctly.

column1: pūrvāṃ saṃdhyāṃ japaṃs tiṣṭhan naiśam eno vyapohati / paścimāṃ tu samāsīno malaṃ hanti divākṛtam //
column2: He who stands during the morning twilight muttering (the Savitri), removes the guilt contracted during the (previous) night; but he who (recites it), seated, in the evening, destroys the sin he committed during the day.

column1: na tiṣṭhati tu yaḥ pūrvāṃ nopāste yaś ca paścimām / sa śūdravad bahiṣkāryaḥ sarvasmād dvijakarmaṇaḥ //
column2: But he who does not (worship) standing in the morning, nor sitting in the evening, shall be excluded, just like a Sudra, from all the duties and rights of an Aryan.

column1: apāṃ samīpe niyato naityakaṃ vidhim āsthitaḥ / sāvitrīm apy adhīyīta gatvāraṇyaṃ samāhitaḥ //
column2: He who (desires to) perform the ceremony (of the) daily (recitation), may even recite the Savitri near water, retiring into the forest, controlling his organs and concentrating his mind.

column1: vedopakaraṇe caiva svādhyāye caiva naityake / nānurodho 'sty anadhyāye homamantreṣu caiva hi //
column2: Both when (one studies) the supplementary treatises of the Veda, and when (one recites) the daily portion of the Veda, no regard need be paid to forbidden days, likewise when (one repeats) the sacred texts required for a burnt oblation.

column1: naityake nāsty anadhyāyo brahmasattraṃ hi tat smṛtam / brahmāhutihutaṃ puṇyam anadhyāyavaṣaṭkṛtam //
column2: There are no forbidden days for the daily recitation, since that is declared to be a Brahmasattra (an everlasting sacrifice offered to Brahman); at that the Veda takes the place of the burnt oblations, and it is meritorious (even), when (natural phenomena, requiring) a cessation of the Veda-study, take the place of the exclamation Vashat.

column1: yaḥ svādhyāyam adhīte 'bdaṃ vidhinā niyataḥ śuciḥ / tasya nityaṃ kṣaraty eṣa payo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu //
column2: For him who, being pure and controlling his organs, during a year daily recites the Veda according to the rule, that (daily recitation) will ever cause sweet and sour milk, clarified butter and honey to flow.

column1: agnīndhanaṃ bhaikṣacaryām adhaḥśayyāṃ guror hitam / ā samāvartanāt kuryāt kṛtopanayano dvijaḥ //
column2: Let an Aryan who has been initiated, (daily) offer fuel in the sacred fire, beg food, sleep on the ground and do what is beneficial to this teacher, until (he performs the ceremony of) Samavartana (on returning home).

column1: ācāryaputraḥ śuśrūṣur jñānado dhārmikaḥ śuciḥ / āptaḥ śakto 'rthadaḥ sādhuḥ svo 'dhyāpyā daśa dharmataḥ //
column2: According to the sacred law the (following) ten (persons, viz.) the teacher's son, one who desires to do service, one who imparts knowledge, one who is intent on fulfilling the law, one who is pure, a person connected by marriage or friendship, one who possesses (mental) ability, one who makes presents of money, one who is honest, and a relative, may be instructed (in the Veda).

column1: nāpṛṣṭaḥ kasya cid brūyān na cānyāyena pṛcchataḥ / jānann api hi medhāvī jaḍaval loka ācaret //
column2: Unless one be asked, one must not explain (anything) to anybody, nor (must one answer) a person who asks improperly; let a wise man, though he knows (the answer), behave among men as (if he were) an idiot.

column1: adharmeṇa ca yaḥ prāha yaś cādharmeṇa pṛcchati / tayor anyataraḥ praiti vidveṣaṃ vādhigacchati //
column2: Of the two persons, him who illegally explains (anything), and him who illegally asks (a question), one (or both) will die or incur (the other's) enmity.

column1: dharmārthau yatra na syātāṃ śuśrūṣā vāpi tadvidhā / tatra vidyā na vaptavyā śubhaṃ bījam ivoṣare //
column2: Where merit and wealth are not (obtained by teaching) nor (at least) due obedience, in such (soil) sacred knowledge must not be sown, just as good seed (must) not (be thrown) on barren land.

column1: vidyayaiva samaṃ kāmaṃ martavyaṃ brahmavādinā / āpady api hi ghorāyāṃ na tv enām iriṇe vapet // vidyā brāhmaṇam etyāha śevadhis te 'smi rakṣa mām / asūyakāya māṃ mādās tathā syāṃ vīryavattamā // yam eva tu śuciṃ vidyān niyatabrahmacāriṇam / tasmai māṃ brūhi viprāya nidhipāyāpramādine //
column2: Even in times of dire distress a teacher of the Veda should rather die with his knowledge than sow it in barren soil. Sacred Learning approached a Brahmana and said to him: 'I am thy treasure, preserve me, deliver me not to a scorner; so (preserved) I shall become supremely strong.' 'But deliver me, as to the keeper of thy treasure, to a Brahmana whom thou shalt know to be pure, of subdued senses, chaste and attentive.'

column1: brahma yas tv ananujñātam adhīyānād avāpnuyāt / sa brahmasteyasaṃyukto narakaṃ pratipadyate //
column2: But he who acquires without permission the Veda from one who recites it, incurs the guilt of stealing the Veda, and shall sink into hell.

column1: laukikaṃ vaidikaṃ vāpi tathādhyātmikam eva vā / ādadīta yato jñānaṃ taṃ pūrvam abhivādayet //
column2: (A student) shall first reverentially salute that (teacher) from whom he receives (knowledge), referring to worldly affairs, to the Veda, or to the Brahman.

column1: sāvitrīmātrasāro 'pi varaṃ vipraḥ suyantritaḥ / nāyantritas trivedo 'pi sarvāśī sarvavikrayī //
column2: A Brahmana who completely governs himself, though he know the Savitri only, is better than he who knows the three Vedas, (but) does not control himself, eats all (sorts of) food, and sells all (sorts of goods).

column1: śayyāsane 'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet / śayyāsanasthaś caivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet //
column2: One must not sit down on a couch or seat which a superior occupies; and he who occupies a couch or seat shall rise to meet a (superior), and (afterwards) salute him.

column1: ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hy utkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati / pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punas tān pratipadyate //
column2: For the vital airs of a young man mount upwards to leave his body when an elder approaches; but by rising to meet him and saluting he recovers them.

column1: abhivādanaśīlasya nityaṃ vṛddhopasevinaḥ / catvāri tasya vardhante āyur dharmo yaśo balam //
column2: He who habitually salutes and constantly pays reverence to the aged obtains an increase of four (things), (viz.) length of life, knowledge, fame, (and) strength.

column1: abhivādāt paraṃ vipro jyāyāṃsam abhivādayan / asau nāmāham asmīti svaṃ nāma parikīrtayet //
column2: After the (word of) salutation, a Brahmana who greets an elder must pronounce his name, saying, 'I am N. N.'

column1: nāmadheyasya ye ke cid abhivādaṃ na jānate / tān prājño 'ham iti brūyāt striyaḥ sarvās tathaiva ca //
column2: To those (persons) who, when a name is pronounced, do not understand (the meaning of) the salutation, a wise man should say, 'It is I;' and (he should address) in the same manner all women.

column1: bhoḥśabdaṃ kīrtayed ante svasya nāmno 'bhivādane / nāmnāṃ svarūpabhāvo hi bhobhāva ṛṣibhiḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: In saluting he should pronounce after his name the word bhoh; for the sages have declared that the nature of bhoh is the same as that of (all proper) names.

column1: āyuṣmān bhava saumyeti vācyo vipro 'bhivādane / akāraś cāsya nāmno 'nte vācyaḥ pūrvākṣaraḥ plutaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana should thus be saluted in return, 'May'st thou be long-lived, O gentle one!' and the vowel 'a' must be added at the end of the name (of the person addressed), the syllable preceding it being drawn out to the length of three moras.

column1: yo na vetty abhivādasya vipraḥ pratyabhivādanam / nābhivādyaḥ sa viduṣā yathā śūdras tathaiva saḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who does not know the form of returning a salutation, must not be saluted by a learned man; as a Sudra, even so is he.

column1: brāhmaṇaṃ kuśalaṃ pṛcchet kṣatrabandhum anāmayam / vaiśyaṃ kṣemaṃ samāgamya śūdram ārogyam eva ca //
column2: Let him ask a Brahmana, on meeting him, after (his health, with the word) kusala, a Kshatriya (with the word) anamaya, a Vaisya (with the word) kshema, and a Sudra (with the word) anarogya.

column1: avācyo dīkṣito nāmnā yavīyān api yo bhavet / bhobhavatpūrvakaṃ tv enam abhibhāṣeta dharmavit //
column2: He who has been initiated (to perform a Srauta sacrifice) must not be addressed by his name, even though he be a younger man; he who knows the sacred law must use in speaking to such (a man the particle) bhoh and (the pronoun) bhavat (your worship).

column1: parapatnī tu yā strī syād asaṃbandhā ca yonitaḥ / tāṃ brūyād bhavatīty evaṃ subhage bhaginīti ca //
column2: But to a female who is the wife of another man, and not a blood-relation, he must say, 'Lady' (bhavati) or 'Beloved sister!'

column1: mātulāṃś ca pitṛvyāṃś ca śvaśurān ṛtvijo gurūn / asāv aham iti brūyāt pratyutthāya yavīyasaḥ //
column2: To his maternal and paternal uncles, fathers-in-law, officiating priests, (and other) venerable persons, he must say, 'I am N. N.,' and rise (to meet them), even though they be younger (than himself).

column1: mātṛśvasā mātulānī śvaśrūr atha pitṛśvasā / saṃpūjyā gurupatnīvat samās tā gurubhāryayā //
column2: A maternal aunt, the wife of a maternal uncle, a mother-in-law, and a paternal aunt must be honoured like the wife of one's teacher; they are equal to the wife of one's teacher.

column1: pitur bhaginyāṃ mātuś ca jyāyasyāṃ ca svasary api / mātṛvad vṛttim ātiṣṭhen mātā tābhyo garīyasī //
column2: Towards a sister of one's father and of one's mother, and towards one's own elder sister, one must behave as towards one's mother; (but) the mother is more venerable than they.

column1: daśābdākhyaṃ paurasakhyaṃ pañcābdākhyaṃ kalābhṛtām / tryabdapūrvaṃ śrotriyāṇāṃ svalpenāpi svayoniṣu //
column2: Fellow-citizens are called friends (and equals though one be) ten years (older than the other), men practising (the same) fine art (though one be) five years (older than the other), Srotriyas (though) three years (intervene between their ages), but blood-relations only (if the) difference of age be very small.

column1: brāhmaṇaṃ daśavarṣaṃ tu śatavarṣaṃ tu bhūmipam / pitāputrau vijānīyād brāhmaṇas tu tayoḥ pitā //
column2: Know that a Brahmana of ten years and Kshatriya of a hundred years stand to each other in the relation of father and son; but between those two the Brahmana is the father.

column1: vittaṃ bandhur vayaḥ karma vidyā bhavati pañcamī / etāni mānyasthānāni garīyo yad yad uttaram //
column2: Wealth, kindred, age, (the due performance of) rites, and, fifthly, sacred learning are titles to respect; but each later-named (cause) is more weighty (than the preceding ones).

column1: pañcānāṃ triṣu varṇeṣu bhūyāṃsi guṇavanti ca / yatra syuḥ so 'tra mānārhaḥ śūdro 'pi daśamīṃ gataḥ //
column2: Whatever man of the three (highest) castes possesses most of those five, both in number and degree, that man is worthy of honour among them; and (so is) also a Sudra who has entered the tenth (decade of his life).

column1: cakriṇo daśamīsthasya rogiṇo bhāriṇaḥ striyāḥ / snātakasya ca rājñaś ca panthā deyo varasya ca //
column2: Way must be made for a man in a carriage, for one who is above ninety years old, for one diseased, for the carrier of a burden, for a woman, for a Snataka, for the king, and for a bridegroom.

column1: teṣāṃ tu samāvetānāṃ mānyau snātakapārthivau / rājasnātakayoś caiva snātako nṛpamānabhāk //
column2: Among all those, if they meet (at one time), a Snataka and the king must be (most) honoured; and if the king and a Snataka (meet), the latter receives respect from the king.

column1: upanīya tu yaḥ śiṣyaṃ vedam adhyāpayed dvijaḥ / sakalpaṃ sarahasyaṃ ca tam ācāryaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: They call that Brahmana who initiates a pupil and teaches him the Veda together with the Kalpa and the Rahasyas, the teacher (akarya, of the latter).

column1: ekadeśaṃ tu vedasya vedāṅgāny api vā punaḥ / yo 'dhyāpayati vṛttyartham upādhyāyaḥ sa ucyate //
column2: But he who for his livelihood teaches a portion only of the Veda, or also the Angas of the Veda, is called the sub-teacher (upadhyaya).

column1: niṣekādīni karmāṇi yaḥ karoti yathāvidhi / saṃbhāvayati cānnena sa vipro gurur ucyate //
column2: That Brahmana, who performs in accordance with the rules (of the Veda) the rites, the Garbhadhana (conception-rite), and so forth, and gives food (to the child), is called the Guru (the venerable one).

column1: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñān agniṣṭomādikān makhān / yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvig ihocyate //
column2: He who, being (duly) chosen (for the purpose), performs the Agnyadheya, the Pakayagnas, (and) the (Srauta) sacrifices, such as the Agnishtoma (for another man), is called (his) officiating priest.

column1: ya āvṛṇoty avitathaṃ brahmaṇā śravaṇāv ubhau / sa mātā sa pitā jñeyas taṃ na druhyet kadā cana //
column2: That (man) who truthfully fills both his ears with the Veda, (the pupil) shall consider as his father and mother; he must never offend him.

column1: upādhyāyān daśācārya ācāryāṇāṃ śataṃ pitā / sahasraṃ tu pitṝn mātā gauraveṇātiricyate //
column2: The teacher (akarya) is ten times more venerable than a sub-teacher (upadhyaya), the father a hundred times more than the teacher, but the mother a thousand times more than the father.

column1: utpādakabrahmadātror garīyān brahmadaḥ pitā / brahmajanma hi viprasya pretya ceha ca śāśvatam //
column2: Of him who gives natural birth and him who gives (the knowledge of) the Veda, the giver of the Veda is the more venerable father; for the birth for the sake of the Veda (ensures) eternal (rewards) both in this (life) and after death.

column1: kāmān mātā pitā cainaṃ yad utpādayato mithaḥ / saṃbhūtiṃ tasya tāṃ vidyād yad yonāv abhijāyate //
column2: Let him consider that (he received) a (mere animal) existence, when his parents begat him through mutual affection, and when he was born from the womb (of his mother).

column1: ācāryas tv asya yāṃ jātiṃ vidhivad vedapāragaḥ / utpādayati sāvitryā sā satyā sājarāmarā //
column2: But that birth which a teacher acquainted with the whole Veda, in accordance with the law, procures for him through the Savitri, is real, exempt from age and death.

column1: alpaṃ vā bahu vā yasya śrutasyopakaroti yaḥ / tam apīha guruṃ vidyāc chrutopakriyayā tayā //
column2: (The pupil) must know that that man also who benefits him by (instruction in) the Veda, be it little or much, is called in these (Institutes) his Guru, in consequence of that benefit (conferred by instruction in) the Veda.

column1: brāhmasya janmanaḥ kartā svadharmasya ca śāsitā / bālo 'pi vipro vṛddhasya pitā bhavati dharmataḥ //
column2: That Brahmana who is the giver of the birth for the sake of the Veda and the teacher of the prescribed duties becomes by law the father of an aged man, even though he himself be a child.

column1: adhyāpayām āsa pitṝn śiśur āṅgirasaḥ kaviḥ / putrakā iti hovāca jñānena parigṛhya tān //
column2: Young Kavi, the son of Angiras, taught his (relatives who were old enough to be) fathers, and, as he excelled them in (sacred) knowledge, he called them 'Little sons.'

column1: te tam artham apṛcchanta devān āgatamanyavaḥ / devāś caitān sametyocur nyāyyaṃ vaḥ śiśur uktavān //
column2: They, moved with resentment, asked the gods concerning that matter, and the gods, having assembled, answered, 'The child has addressed you properly.'

column1: ajño bhavati vai bālaḥ pitā bhavati mantradaḥ / ajñaṃ hi bālam ity āhuḥ pitety eva tu mantradam //
column2: 'For (a man) destitute of (sacred) knowledge is indeed a child, and he who teaches him the Veda is his father; for (the sages) have always said "child" to an ignorant man, and "father" to a teacher of the Veda.'

column1: na hāyanair na palitair na vittena na bandhubhiḥ / ṛṣayaś cakrire dharmaṃ yo 'nūcānaḥ sa no mahān //
column2: Neither through years, nor through white (hairs), nor through wealth, nor through (powerful) kinsmen (comes greatness). The sages have made this law, 'He who has learnt the Veda together with the Angas (Anukana) is (considered) great by us.'

column1: viprāṇāṃ jñānato jyaiṣṭhyaṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu vīryataḥ / vaiśyānāṃ dhānyadhanataḥ śūdrāṇām eva janmataḥ //
column2: The seniority of Brahmanas is from (sacred) knowledge, that of Kshatriyas from valour, that of Vaisyas from wealth in grain (and other goods), but that of Sudras alone from age.

column1: na tena vṛddho bhavati yenāsya palitaṃ śiraḥ / yo vai yuvāpy adhīyānas taṃ devāḥ sthaviraṃ viduḥ //
column2: A man is not therefore (considered) venerable because his head is gray; him who, though young, has learned the Veda, the gods consider to be venerable.

column1: yathā kāṣṭhamayo hastī yathā carmamayo mṛgaḥ / yaś ca vipro 'nadhīyānas trayas te nāma bibhrati //
column2: As an elephant made of wood, as an antelope made of leather, such is an unlearned Brahmana; those three have nothing but the names (of their kind).

column1: yathā ṣaṇḍho 'phalaḥ strīṣu yathā gaur gavi cāphalā / yathā cājñe 'phalaṃ dānaṃ tathā vipro 'nṛco 'phalaḥ //
column2: As a eunuch is unproductive with women, as a cow with a cow is unprolific, and as a gift made to an ignorant man yields no reward, even so is a Brahmana useless, who (does) not (know) the Rikas.

column1: ahiṃsayaiva bhūtānāṃ kāryaṃ śreyo 'nuśāsanam / vāk caiva madhurā ślakṣṇā prayojyā dharmam icchatā //
column2: Created beings must be instructed in (what concerns) their welfare without giving them pain, and sweet and gentle speech must be used by (a teacher) who desires (to abide by) the sacred law.

column1: yasya vāṅganasī śuddhe samyaggupte ca sarvadā / sa vai sarvam avāpnoti vedāntopagataṃ phalam //
column2: He, forsooth, whose speech and thoughts are pure and ever perfectly guarded, gains the whole reward which is conferred by the Vedanta.

column1: nāruṃtudaḥ syād ārto 'pi na paradrohakarmadhīḥ / yayāsyodvijate vācā nālokyāṃ tām udīrayet //
column2: Let him not, even though in pain, (speak words) cutting (others) to the quick; let him not injure others in thought or deed; let him not utter speeches which make (others) afraid of him, since that will prevent him from gaining heaven.

column1: sammānād brāhmaṇo nityam udvijeta viṣād iva / amṛtasyeva cākāṅkṣed avamānasya sarvadā //
column2: A Brahmana should always fear homage as if it were poison; and constantly desire (to suffer) scorn as (he would long for) nectar.

column1: sukhaṃ hy avamataḥ śete sukhaṃ ca pratibudhyate / sukhaṃ carati loke 'sminn avamantā vinaśyati //
column2: For he who is scorned (nevertheless may) sleep with an easy mind, awake with an easy mind, and with an easy mind walk here among men; but the scorner utterly perishes.

column1: anena kramayogena saṃskṛtātmā dvijaḥ śanaiḥ / gurau vasan sañcinuyād brahmādhigamikaṃ tapaḥ // tapoviśeṣair vividhair vrataiś ca vidhicoditaiḥ / vedaḥ kṛtsno 'dhigantavyaḥ sarahasyo dvijanmanā //
column2: A twice-born man who has been sanctified by the (employment of) the means, (described above) in due order, shall gradually and cumulatively perform the various austerities prescribed for (those who) study the Veda. An Aryan must study the whole Veda together with the Rahasyas, performing at the same time various kinds of austerities and the vows prescribed by the rules (of the Veda).

column1: vedam eva sadābhyasyet tapas tapsyan dvijottamaḥ / vedābhyāso hi viprasya tapaḥ param ihocyate //
column2: Let a Brahmana who desires to perform austerities, constantly repeat the Veda; for the study of the Veda is declared (to be) in this world the highest austerity for a Brahmana.
